Award.AwardTitle: A Descriptive and Theoretical Analysis of Complex Predicates in Iranian Languages

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Verbal information is conveyed differently in the world languages. In English, this information is mostly expressed by a simple verb, while in some other languages it is conveyed by a complex structure consisting of two or more components linguists call complex predicates. For example, gerye kardan 'cry doing' (Farsi) translates as the single verb 'to cry' in English. This project focuses on a descriptive and theoretical analysis of complex predicates in seventeen Iranian languages.

The nature of complex predicates has been the subject of many linguistic studies in the last 5-6 decades. One major question is whether they are word-like, or rather phrase-like with each component revealing independent properties. Furthermore, the contribution of each part to the meaning of the whole have long been a central issue in linguistic theory. Crucially, complex predicates reveal distinct behavior with respect to certain constructions compared to those observed in well-studied languages such as English. These constructions include passives (The apple was eaten), resultatives (John wiped the table clean), and causatives (John made Mary leave). The nature of these differences, and the reasons for their existence, are not well understood. New data and the microparametric comparison of the Iranian languages will break new ground in our understanding of the underpinnings of complex predicate formation and their behavior in human language.

Data collection will be conducted via linguistic elicitation with native speaker consultants as well as Complex Predicate Questionnaires to be filled out by native speaker consultants trained in linguistics. One of the goals of this project is to transcribe, catalogue and enter the data into a database. All the textual material that forms the basis for the descriptive analysis and pedagogical material will be stored in an accessible format available to public for further study, in addition to a web-based encyclopedia for the target languages. This study promises many benefits. It trains several students as experts in Iranian languages, provides understanding of languages and cultures Americans are interested in, but do not know much about, and fosters research relations between linguists in three continents, which will enrich collaborative activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A Descriptive and Theoretical Analysis of Complex Predicates in Iranian Languages

 

Verbal information is conveyed differently in the world languages.  In English, this information is mostly expressed by a simple verb, while in some other languages it is conveyed by a complex structure consisting of two or more components linguists call complex predicates.  For example, the English verb ?cry? translates as gerye kardan ?cry doing? in a language like Persian. 

 

The goal of this study was to investigate complex predicates (CPr) in eighteen Iranian languages and dialects. The Iranian language family is a branch of the Indo-Iranian languages, the easternmost major subgroup of Indo-European language family. Iranian languages are spoken in Iran, parts of Pakistan, Afghanistan, Iraq, Turkey and Georgia.  The target languages and dialects for this study consisted of Persian, Dari, Pashto, Sorani-Kurdish, Ardalani-Kurdish, Kurmanji-Kurdish, Mazandarani, Balochi, Zazaki, Tat, Ossetian, Hawrami, Laki, Lori, Bakhtiari, Kalhori, Behbahani, and Gilaki.  The majority of these languages and dialects are understudied at best. Thus the main objective of this study was to discover new information about a language family that was greatly unknown to scholars in the field in order to enrich our knowledge regarding the nature of human language, in general, and the predicate formation, in particular. 

 

Building on previous work by two of the Principal Investigators and other authors, this project pursued three main goals:

 

Frist, to develop an extensive classification system of complex predicates for eighteen Iranian languages and dialects, and describe the structure, meaning, and word formation patterns of these constructions.  

 

Second, to apply the results of the descriptive analysis to evaluate the theoretical adequacy of the treatments of these constructions. Our major research question concerned the nature of complex predicates in human language by concentrating on Iranian languages with a rich system of complex predicate formation.  

 

 Third, to transcribe, catalogue and enter the data into a database accessible to the public, and use the data to create content for Wikipedia pages on a number of the target language, also accessible to public. 

 

Major outcomes

  • The database consisting of the original interviews conducted on eighteen Iranian languages and the transcriptions of the data were uploaded to the university-managed, password-protected data-storage at the University of Arizona. (https://repository.arizona.edu/handle/10150/626265)  The University of Arizona Campus Repository is an institutional repository that facilitates access to the research, creative works, publications and teaching materials of the University by collecting, sharing and archiving content selected and deposited by faculty, researchers, staff and affiliated contributors.  

 

  • Wikipedia style pages for seven Iranian languages (Balochi, Gilaki, Manandarani, Ossetian, Pashto, Sorani and Kurmanji) were created.  These pages, consisting of descriptions of cultural and linguistic specifications of these languages, including basic descriptions of the sound systems, word formations and structures of these languages, have been uploaded to the webpage of the College of Social and Behavioral Sciences, home of the Department of Linguistics.  They will become accessible to public in the Fall of 2020.

 

  • The investigators and their research assistants presented scholarly articles at various national and international conferences.  Some of these presentations were invited lectures, and some peer reviewed conference talks. Three articles have been produces, authored by two Principal Investigators and several graduate students.  One of these articles is already published, and the other two are under review by two prestigious linguistics journals. A fourth article is in progress.  

 

  • This grant provided significant training for students.  Five graduate students and two undergraduate students were involved with this study throughout the life of the grant.  They attended the weekly meetings consisting of literature review and data analysis, contacted language consultants, and participated in the elicitation sessions. The graduate research assistants were also involved in writing abstract for conference presentations, producing actual articles, transcribing the data and entering them into the database, preparing Wikipedia pages, communicating with people in charge of the university wide webpage for transferring all interviews and data, and with the people in the college to transfer the Wikipedia pages to the college webpage.  In addition to the students who served as research assistants and associates, 3-4 other graduate students were regularly attending the weekly meetings, and participated in discussions.

 

  • Thanks to the supplemental funds to the original award, the research team was able to organize a one day workshop on complex predicates in Iranian Languages. Eight papers were presented at this workshop, two of them by invited speakers, and the remaining six by students from various universities in Korea, Turkey, Germany and the States.  The complex predicate research team had a one hour presentation, reporting the results of their research at this workshop.
